conclusion: To determine the speed of rod b, we need to analyze the forces acting on both rods and the induced electromotive force (EMF) due to their motion in the magnetic field.
The induced EMF in rod a due to its motion is given by: \( \mathcal{E} = B L v_a \).
B = 0.2 T is the magnetic field strength, L = 0.5 m is the length of the rods, v_a = 1.0 m/s is the velocity of rod a.
The total resistance of the circuit is the sum of the resistances of rods a and b: \( R_{\text{total}} = R_a + R_b = 0.1 \, \Omega + 0.1 \, \Omega = 0.2 \, \Omega \).
The current I in the circuit is given by Ohm's Law: \( I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R_{\text{total}}} = \frac{0.1}{0.2} = 0.5 \, \text{A} \).
The magnetic force F_{a} on rod a is: \( F_{a} = B I L = 0.2 \times 0.5 \times 0.5 = 0.05 \, \text{N} \).
F = 2 N is the applied force, m_a = 0.3 kg, g = 10 m/s^2, \( \theta = 30^\circ \).
The gravitational component is: \( m_a g \sin \theta = 0.3 \times 10 \times \sin 30^\circ = 0.3 \times 10 \times 0.5 = 1.5 \, \text{N} \).

premise: F = 2 N, F_{a} = 0.05 N, m_a g \sin \theta = 1.5 N
conclusion: The net force on rod a is: \( F_{\text{net},a} = F - F_{a} - m_a g \sin \theta = 2 - 0.05 - 1.5 = 0.45 \, \text{N} \).
